text: Mexico gains independence from Spain
Joel Robert Poinsett embarks on a special mission to Mexico, publishing an account of his experiences in 'Notes on Mexico'
The United States recognizes Mexico as an independent nation
United States president James Monroe articulates the Monroe Doctrine in his seventh annual message to Congress
Joel Robert Poinsett is appointed first U.S. minister to Mexico
Over several years, empresario Stephen F. Austin attracts the first 300 American families into the Coahuilas y Tejas territory
American empresario Haden Edwards leads Fredonian Rebellion in an attempt to secede from Mexico
Mexico abolishes slavery
Mexican-owned Tejas is home to roughly 20,000 Americans
Mexico prohibits immigration to Tejas from the United States in an effort to stop the influx of English-speaking settlers
American immigrants and Tejanos lead the Texas Revolution on behalf of the Tejas province of Mexico as part of a larger Mexican Federalist's War
The Battle of the Alamo
An independent Republic of Texas is declared during the Texas Convention
Santa Anna surrenders after defeat in Battle of San Jacinto; Treaties of Valasco unofficially marks Rio Grande as the border between Mexico and the Republic of Texas
Mexico defends itself successfully from French invasion during the 'Pastry War'; Santa Anna's role helps him regain popularity
Santa Anna returns to the Mexican presidency, ordering the military to pressure the Mexican-Texas border
San Antonio is taken and returned several times; a back-and-forth of Mexican militants and Tejanos crossing the border for raids and returning to Mexico continues
Expansionist Democrat James K. Polk becomes U.S. President
Mexico refuses to negotiate the acceptance of Texas' annexation into the United States
Republic of Texas annexed into the United States as the 28th state
President James K. Polk orders General Zachary Taylor to occupy disputed territory between the Nueces and Rio Grande rivers
Mexican troops at Matamoros cross the Rio Grande and ambush an American patrol, which President Polk declares an act of war
Mexican-American War begins
The United States army marches towards Mexico City from the north while the United States navy takes Veracruz via amphibious assault
The United States army takes and occupies Mexico City
The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo is signed, ending the Mexican-American War
Gadsden Purchase is finalized and signed, forming the current day borders between the United States and Mexico
Invoking the Monroe Doctrine, the United States provides diplomatic and material support to Mexico during the French Intervention in Mexico
Mexico encourages repatriation of Mexican-Americans back into its northern territories
Porfirio Díaz seizes power in Mexico with the financial support of U.S. entrepreneurs from South Texas
The Porfiriato government strengthens U.S. - Mexico economic ties through mining and railroad investments
Discontent with the Porfiriato leads to Mexican Revolution, U.S. involvement and interventions strain relations
'Pact of the Embassy' brokered by US ambassador Henry Lane Wilson to Mexico, leading to Francisco Madero's assassination and Victoriano Huerta's ascension to Mexican presidency
Woodrow Wilson elected President of the United States and embargoes weapons and supplies to Huerta's Mexican Federalist troops
President Wilson sends US marines to occupy Mexico's port of Veracruz, heightening tensions between the two countries
President Wilson orders the Pancho Villa Expedition, which ultimately fails
President Wilson and Venustiano Carranza agree to a Joint High Commission, leading to the withdrawal of US troops from Mexican territory
Venustiano Carranza elected president of Mexico
Zimmermann telegram is intercepted by the British and sent to the United States, swaying public opinion in favor of joining the World War
Bucareli Agreement of 1923
'Good Neighbor Policy' implemented by US President Franklin Delano Roosevelt
Lázaro Cárdenas expropriates and redistributes more than six million acres of U.S.-owned property in Mexico during his presidency
Cárdenas nationalizes Mexico's petroleum sector
Roosevelt pushes US owners of oil companies to end their boycott of Mexican crude oil and accept adequate compensation for repossessed properties
Mexico stops trading with Germany
Mexico stops trading with Italy and Japan
Mexican President Manuel Ávila Camacho severs relations with Japan, Germany, and Italy after the attack on Pearl Harbor
Mexico declares war on the Axis powers
Bracero Program starts, allowing Mexican agricultural workers to work temporarily in the US
Mexican expeditionary fighter squadron “Aztec Eagles” gives aid to US efforts in the Philippines
250,000 Mexicans and a million Mexican Americans serve in the U.S. armed forces during WW2
Some 300,000 U.S. tourists visit Mexico annually
Mexican leaders praise the Cuban Revolution and refuse to sever diplomatic ties with Castro's government, despite pressure from the US President John F Kennedy
Bracero program ends
The U.S. introduces the Immigration and Nationality Act, changing how immigration quotas are managed
United States backs the Institutional Revolutionary Party during the Tlatelolco Massacre
US President Richard Nixon launches Operation Intercept, causing US customs officials to begin searching each and every border-crossing vehicle for drugs
Drug Enforcement Administration is established in the US to coordinate drug enforcement efforts
Mexican government begins Operation Condor in an effort to eradicate and interdict drugs
Guadalajara cartel, one of the first major Mexican drug cartels, is formed
Mexico signs agreement with the International Monetary Fund to reschedule debt payments, opening foreign trade and investment
US leaders grudgingly accept Mexican support for Nicaragua's Sandinista government and lead efforts to find peaceful resolutions to conflicts in the region
DEA agent Enrique 'Kiki' Camarena is kidnapped, tortured, and murdered by the Guadalajara Cartel, leading to increased U.S.-Mexico cooperation on drug enforcement
The US begins the certification process, evaluating countries' efforts in combating drug trafficking. Non-cooperative countries risk losing US aid and trade benefits

Immigration and Reform Control Act allocates new resources to the Border Patrol, sanctions US employers who hire illegal workers, and offers amnesty legalization to long-term undocumented residents and agricultural workers
North American Free Trade Agreement, or NAFTA, deepens US and Mexican economic ties
California adopts Proposition 187, denying undocumented residents access to nearly all public services, including schools and hospitals
Congress passes the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996
Mexico passes the 1996 Constitutional Amendment on Dual Nationality
General Jesús Gutiérrez Rebollo, Mexico's top anti-drug official, is arrested for protecting a cartel leader, highlighting corruption issues
Marking the end of 71 years of Institutional Revolutionary Party rule, Vicente Fox is elected President of Mexico, promising to combat drug cartels
